contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “loved” implies a relationship of loyalty between Yahweh and Jacob, in which a covenant existed between them. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “as you know, I obligated myself with a covenant to love Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
This implies that those who are weeping at Yahweh’s altar have offered sacrifices to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: does not turn toward the offering

contextId.occurrenceNote: The complete idea here is, “You have wearied him by saying.” This is the prophet’s answer to the rhetorical question. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

That is, turning away the foreigner from gaining his rights. Depriving people of their rights is spoken of as if it were physically turning them away from oneself. Perhaps the idea is turning away someone who comes for a wrong to be set right. Alternate translation: “deny foreigners living in Israel the rights that they should have” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This reply from Yahweh implies a fuller answer. Alternate translation: “You have robbed me by withholding from me your tithes and offerings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
That is, “they escape God’s punishment.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

The command in the first sentence functions as a hypothetical condition. Alternate translation: “If you present that to your governor, will he accept you or will he lift up your face?” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-imperative]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Present that to your governor! Will he accept you or will he lift up your face?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Malachi asks these questions in order to remind his fellow Israelites about what they already know. Alternate translation: “You know that we all have one father, that our God has created a nation out of us.” or “You all know that God is the father of all us Israelites, because he is the one who made our nation.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is there not one father for us all? Has not one God created us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This statement assumes that this woman is still living. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh was a witness between you and the wife of your youth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This statement implies that many of the Israelites had divorced their wives. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: she was your companion and your wife by covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression implies making husband and wife one flesh. Alternate translation: “make husband and wife one flesh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “weeping” and “sighing” share similar meanings and intensify the idea of weeping. Alternate translation: “with great weeping” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])

This is the answer that Yahweh gives to the priests, but the full answer is only implied. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “You have polluted me by saying, ‘Yahweh’s table is contemptible.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: By saying that Yahweh’s table is contemptible.

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression continues the same metaphor, but leaves out an idea that is implied in the text. This can begin a new sentence. Alternate translation: “My covenant with him was also fear, and he feared me” or “In my covenant with him, I required him to fear me, and he did fear me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])

This sarcastically exaggerates the amount of tears the people cry to show that Yahweh knows that the people do not really feel sad. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: You cover the altar of Yahweh with tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “by the hand of” is an idiom that means that Yahweh used Malachi to deliver his message. Alternate translation: “through Malachi” or “spoken to them by Malachi” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
Lifting up someone’s face refers to accepting him with favor. Alternate translation: “will he accept you with favor” or “will he agree to help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: will he lift up your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lifting up someone’s face refers to accepting him with favor. Alternate translation: “would he accept any of you with favor” or “would he agree to help any of you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: would he lift up any of your faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: show great disrespect by making noises through the nose (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This refers to considering something to be very important. Alternate translation: “consider it to be very important” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
This refers to considering God’s command to be very important. Alternate translation: “you are not considering my command to be very important” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you are not laying my command on your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression seems to mean “absolutely everyone.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who is awake and the one who answers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase probably means any man who is violent toward his wife. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who covers his garment with violence

contextId.occurrenceNote: This double expression means “everywhere.” It is parallel to “among the nations” and “in every place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: from the rising of the sun to its setting

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression continues to speak of people as if they were plants or trees. So being deprived of all roots and branches stands for being completely killed off. Alternate translation: “nothing will be left” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will leave them neither root nor branch

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “inheritance” stands for the region that Esau’s descendants, the nation of Edom, occupied. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here “polluted” describes anything that is not suitable to sacrifice to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
This expression refers to insulting God by giving him unsuitable sacrifices. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here “dung on your faces” stands for disgrace. Alternate translation: “I will most certainly put you in deep disgrace; it will be as bad as if I had spread dung on your faces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will spread dung on your faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) God will punish the unfaithful priests by killing them and causing their bodies to be carried away on the piles of animal dung, or (2) God will punish the unfaithful priests in such a horrible way that it will be as if their bodies had been carried away with the animal dung. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will take you away with it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the intended results of the covenant are spoken of as if they were the covenant itself. Alternate translation: “The purpose of my covenant with Levi was for the priests to live in prosperity and peace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My covenant with him was life and peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here walking stands for living, conducting one’s life in a certain way. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here the idea of location stands for the manner in which Levi lived. Alternate translation: “peacefully and uprightly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here persuading people to stop sinning is spoken of as if it were turning them away from sin. Alternate translation: “he persuaded many people to stop sinning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he turned many away from sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lips” stands for a person’s ability to speak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here knowledge is spoken of as if it were an object that a priest could keep. In this passage, the idea of “keep knowledge” implies communicating true knowledge about God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For a priest’s lips should keep knowledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: The right way to behave is spoken of as if it were the right path to follow, and abandoning right conduct is spoken of as if it were turning away from that path. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you have turned away from the true path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disobeying God is spoken of as if it were stumbling. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have caused many to stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This spatial idea stands for the people’s awareness of the priests’ evil behavior. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here “ways” stands for “desires” and “behavior.” These ways are spoken of as if they were things that could be kept by people. Alternate translation: “followed my desires in how you should live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here the habit of favoring some people more than others is spoken of as if it were a thing that could be shown to others. Alternate translation: “made people aware that you favor some people more than others (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Destroying something is often spoken of as it were cutting it off from something else. Alternate translation: “May Yahweh destroy anyone in the tents of Jacob who” or “May Yahweh kill anyone in the community of Israel who” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: May Yahweh cut off from the tents of Jacob the man who

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “tents of Jacob” stands for the community of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here a witness to an agreement between two people is thought of as standing between them in order to testify about what they agreed to, in case a dispute arises between the two people. This sentence also was meant to remind the people that Yahweh would punish any Israelite who broke the covenant of marriage. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: a witness between you and the wife of your youth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if human behavior could make him tired, but God cannot grow weary in a physical or emotional sense. This statement probably means that Yahweh has become offended or exasperated. Alternate translation: “You have offended Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “in the opinion” or “in the judgment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here getting people ready to welcome Yahweh is spoken of as if a road were being cleared for Yahweh to travel on. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will prepare the way before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here standing represents resisting someone’s attack or accusations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Forgiving the sons of Levi and persuading them not to sin any longer is spoken of as if it were purifying metal. Alternate translation: “he will correct the sons of Levi and forgive them for having sinned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will purify the sons of Levi

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sons” refers to descendants. The male descendants of Levi were the priests and workers in the temple. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Disobeying God’s statutes is spoken of as if it were turning away from them. Alternate translation: “You have disobeyed my statutes ever since the days of your ancestors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: From the days of your fathers you have turned aside from my statutes and have not kept them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here loving each other and being faithful to each other is spoken of as if it were returning to each other. Alternate translation: “Love me and honor me, and I will always help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Return to me, and I will return to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” stands for the temple. Alternate translation: “my temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

Here the command “test me” stands for something that the people can do and should do: “if you test me.” This can be divided into two sentences also. Alternate translation: “And if you test me … I will open up the windows of heaven” or “And you should test me … If you do, I will open up the windows of heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: and test me now in this & if I do not open to you the windows of heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to be called blessed stands for being blessed. Alternate translation: “All the nations will know that you have been blessed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: All the nations will call you blessed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “strong” stands for “harsh” or “terrible.” And “Your words” stands for “What you have said.” Alternate translation: “What you have said about me is terrible” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Your words against me have been strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “walk mournfully” stands for “behave in a sorrowful manner,” probably in order to indicate sorrow over their sins. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walked mournfully before Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this expression refers to God being aware of what the people were doing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here to be called “blessed” stands for being blessed. Alternate translation: “we say that the arrogant are blessed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
The disaster occurring at this time is spoken of as if the day itself were burning. God’s judgment is often spoken of as if it were a fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the day is coming, burning like a furnace

contextId.occurrenceNote: These people are spoken of as if they will become dried-up plants fit only for being burned. It is common for the Bible to speak of people as if they were plants or trees. Alternate translation: “all the arrogant and all the evildoers will burn up like dry plants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: all the arrogant and all the evildoers will become stubble

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was common in the Ancient Near East to speak of the sun as if it had wings, with which it moved across the sky. This could mean: (1) the sun’s life-giving rays of light are spoken of as if they were its wings or (2) the wings are said to cover God’s people so as to give them peace and safey. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
Here the victory of God’s people is spoken of as if they were walking over the burned bodies of their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will trample down the wicked, for they will be ashes under the soles of your feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the occurrence of this day is spoken of as if it were coming. Alternate translation: “before the great and fearful day of Yahweh happens” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the coming of the great and fearful day of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here changing how people think is spoken of as if it were turning their hearts. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Edom” stands for the people of Edom. Alternate translation: “If the people of Edom say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “throw down” stands for “destroy.” Alternate translation: “I will destroy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “my name” stands for Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “treat me as though you hate me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Here “light fires on my altar” stands for offering sacrifices on Yahweh’s altar. Alternate translation: “so that you might not make fires to burn offerings that I will not accept” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: so that you might not light fires on my altar in vain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my name” stands for Yahweh’s reputation and honor. Alternate translation: “I will be honored in other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my name will be great among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” stands for Yahweh. Alternate translation: “to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “my name” stands for Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I will be honored” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here this expression refers to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Here “festivals” stands for the animals that the priests offered in sacrifice at the Israelite festivals. “The dung” probably refers both to the dung that was produced by the animals just before they were slaughtered for sacrifice, and to the dung that was found inside the animals when their bodies were cut apart before being sacrificed. Temple workers had to transport this dung to a place outside of the temple, and probably outside of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here Levi represents his descendants, the tribe of Levi. Alternate translation: “so that my covenant may be with you, the descendants of Levi” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

# General Information:

Yahweh speaks of the tribe of Levi as though they are Levi. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “my name” stands for God himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here finding something stands for that thing existing. Alternate translation: “there was no falsehood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “lips” stands for a person’s ability to speak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “mouth” stands for what a person says. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

Here “Judah” stands for the people in the region of Judah, and the fact that they have been faithless to Yahweh is spoken of as if they were one man named “Judah.” Alternate translation: “The people of Judah have been faithless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “Judah” refers again to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “For the people of Judah have profaned the holy place of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For Judah has profaned the holy place of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Judah are again referred to as if they were one man named “Judah.” Alternate translation: “have married women from other nations, women who worship idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: has married the daughter of a foreign god

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” stands for all the Israelites, because Jacob was one of the patriarchs from whom the Israelites were descended. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here turning toward a gift stands for receiving it and showing favor to the giver. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: does not turn toward the offering

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” and “Jerusalem” stand for the people in those places. Alternate translation: “the offerings brought by the people of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the offering of Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression stands for the people in all the nations. Alternate translation: “The people in all the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “his name” stands for God himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “the day” stands for the events that will occur on that day. Alternate translation: “On that day I will burn them up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The day that is coming will burn them up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my name” stands for Yahweh himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
Here “all Israel” is a reference to all the people in the nation of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the offering was once pleasing to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “as it was in the distant past” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: as in the days of old, and as in ancient years

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question indicates that the people doubt the truth of what God says. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have not shown that you love us.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

This question, a reply of Yahweh reminding the people of their nation’s history, may also be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: “You know that Esau was Jacob’s brother.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Here the priests are asking a question in order to state that they have not really despised Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We have not really despised your name.” or “Tell us how we have despised your name, because we do not think that we have done so.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How have we despised your name?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the priests are asking a question in order to state that they have not really polluted Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We have not polluted you.” or “Tell us how we have polluted you, because we do not think that we have done so.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

Here Yahweh uses a question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: “You know very well that it is evil for you to offer blind animals for sacrifice!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: When you offer blind animals for sacrifice, is that not evil?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh uses a question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: “And you know very well that it is evil for you to offer lame and sick animals!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: When you offer the lame and sick, is that not evil?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh asks this question in order to remind the people that their governor would never accept defective animals from them. Alternate translation: “If you do those things, you know that the governor will not accept you. He will not lift up your face.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Will he accept you or will he lift up your face?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is asking a question in order to make a statement of rebuke. Alternate translation: “if you offer unacceptable offerings, he will certainly not lift up your faces.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: with such an offering in your hand, would he lift up any of your faces?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is asking a question in order to make a statement of rebuke. Alternate translation: “I should certainly not accept this from you!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should I accept this from your hand?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is meant to express a statement. Alternate translation: “Certainly it is the same God who has created us.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Has not one God created us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Malachi asks this question in order to rebuke his fellow Israelites. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We should certainly not mistreat our brothers and disrespect God’s covenant by disobeying his commands, as you have been doing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why are we faithless each man against his brother, profaning the covenant of our fathers?

contextId.occurrenceNote: If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “He certainly made husband and wife one, with a portion of his spirit.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Did he not make them one, with a portion of his spirit?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is meant to deny that the people have done any wrong. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We have certainly not wearied him.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

The priests ask this question in order to claim either that Yahweh does not care whether people do evil or not, or that he never punishes evildoers. Alternate translation: “God certainly does not punish evil people!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is the God of justice?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These rhetorical questions imply that no one will be able to resist Yahweh when he comes. They can be combined into one statement. Alternate translation: “However, no one will be able to resist Yahweh when he comes to judge them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: But who will be able to endure the day of his coming? Who will be able to stand when he appears?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people ask this question in order to claim that they have never stopped obeying God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We have never gone away from you, so we cannot return to you.” or “We have never gone away from you, so it makes no sense to speak of us as returning to you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

This question implies that the idea of robbing God is very wicked. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. God speaks of himself in the third person Alternate translation: “A man should certainly not rob God.” or “No one should ever rob me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
This question implies that the people do not think they have robbed God. Alternate translation: “We have certainly not robbed you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

The people ask this question in order to claim that they have said nothing against God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We have not said anything among ourselves against you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What have we said among ourselves against you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people ask this question among themselves in order to make a statement. Alternate translation: “It is useless that we have kept his requirements and walked mournfully before Yahweh of hosts.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What profit is it that we have kept his requirements or walked mournfully before Yahweh of hosts?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence gives the reason why no one will be able to resist God when he comes. God’s power to judge the people and to stop them from sinning is spoken of as if it were the power of strong soap to clean clothes, or the power of fire to melt an object. These are ways of saying that God’s power to do these things cannot be stopped. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: For he will be like a refiner’s fire and like laundry soap

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sitting implies the action of a metalworker, who sits down in order to purify small amounts of gold or silver. It also implies the action of a king, who sits down to judge people and give decrees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
Here persuading people not to sin any longer is spoken of as if a metalworker were making gold and silver more pure. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: He will refine them like gold and silver

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the redeemed people of Yahweh are spoken of as if they were young bulls released from their stalls, allowed to go out into their pasture. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: You will go out, and you will leap like calves from the stall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This name “Jacob” refers here not only to Jacob, but also to all his descendants. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
This name “Esau” refers here not only to Esau, but also to all his descendants. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “your own eyes” stands for the people themselves. Alternate translation: “You yourselves will see this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Your own eyes will see this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” stands for God and also for his presence. Alternate translation: “keep asking God in his presence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: keep asking the face of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” stands for the people bringing the offering. Alternate translation: “brought by you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “your hand” stands for “you.” Alternate translation: “from you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “your hand” stands for “you.” Alternate translation: “from you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “hand” stands for the person giving the offering. Alternate translation: “from you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
Here “wickedness” stands either for wicked people or for wicked actions. Alternate translation: “country of wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **honor**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “honor my name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **curse**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “I will curse you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will send a curse on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here instruction is spoken of as if it were an object that people could look for. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word ****, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “want to be instructed” or “want a priest to teach them truly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Here “divorce” stands for the act of divorce, when a man sends away his wife, so as to end his marriage to her. Alternate translation: “I hate it when a man divorces his wife” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
Here “judgment” refers to the act of judging. Alternate translation: “Then I will approach you in order to judge you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Then I will approach you for judgment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “delight” stands for the condition in which the inhabitants of a land take delight in their land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
This expression refers to any book that helps people remember important things, such as events or people who lived in the past. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

Here “possession” refers to one’s personal property. This idea can be expressed with a verb. Alternate translation: “they will belong completely to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

This could mean: (1) the act of healing someone is spoken of as if it were an object that the sun carried to people by means of its wings or (2) the healing takes place under the wings, that is, in the security God gives his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **teaching**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “taught.” Alternate translation: “Remember what I taught my servant Moses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Remember the teaching of my servant Moses that I gave him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “in these nations people will offer incense and pure offerings to me in order to worship me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: in every place incense and pure offerings will be offered in my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “people in the other nations honor my name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: my name will be honored among the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This difficult expression can be translated as “God will take you away with it,” that is, with the dung. This expression continues the same metaphor of slaughtering animals for sacrifice, and it can be put in active form. Alternate translation: “they will throw you on the dung pile; God will make sure that they take you away when they remove all the dung” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he will take you away with it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “People have done disgusting things in Israel and in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: A disgusting thing has been committed in Israel and in Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I have certainly cursed you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: You are cursed with a curse

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “we say that the arrogant are well off” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
